Introduction

Dermatoses of pregnancy are pruritic disorders that occur during pregnancy or the immediate postpartum period.  Patients with new-onset pruritus in pregnancy require immediate evaluation because some of the disorders can cause obstetric complications and increase the risk for fetal morbidity and mortality.



Notably, intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is sometimes classified as a dermatosis of pregnancy; however, because of the absence of a rash and no specific management, it is discussed in another article.

Atopic eruption of pregnancy

Pathogenesis and risk factors 



Although not completely understood, the pathogenesis of atopic eruption of pregnancy is likely similar to that of atopic dermatitis (eczema) outside of pregnancy, involving immune dysfunction (eg, a T-helper 2 [Th2]-skewed response) and genetically mediated epidermal barrier dysfunction (loss-of-function of filaggrin).  Loss-of-function mutations result in decreased natural moisturizing factors, impaired keratin filament aggregation, and decreased tight junction expression.



The observed immune dysfunction is likely due to physiologic alterations in immune function during pregnancy, particularly changes in T-helper cell activity that lead to increased Th2 cytokine production and decreased Th1 cytokine production, causing increased skin sensitivity and reactivity.

Clinical features



Patients typically develop symptoms in the first and second trimesters of pregnancy.  The presentation is similar to eczema outside of pregnancy and includes:



  • Pruritic, eczematous patches, papules, and/or plaques
  • Lesions that primarily affect the face, neck, trunk, and flexor surfaces

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of atopic eruption of pregnancy is clinical based on history and physical examination findings.  Skin biopsy is typically performed only in nonclassic cases.  If biopsy is performed, histologic findings include spongiosis (ie, epidermal intercellular edema) and infiltration by T cells, eosinophils, and mast cells.

Management



Most cases of atopic eruption of pregnancy are treated with skin hydration (eg, topical emollients) and possibly antihistamines.  Patients who remain symptomatic following treatment may require low-dose topical corticosteroids.

Prognosis



Atopic eruption of pregnancy does not increase the risk of maternal or fetal complications.  However, recurrence in subsequent pregnancies is likely.

Polymorphic eruption of pregnancy (PEP) 



Polymorphic eruption of pregnancy (PEP) (

), also known as pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy (PUPPP), is a benign, inflammatory condition of pregnancy.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



PEP occurs when overstretching of the skin causes underlying connective tissue damage, which exposes dermal antigens and causes an inflammatory response.  Therefore, it is more common in primigravidas (due to the lack of previous skin stretching) and in patients with multiple gestations or excessive weight gain during pregnancy.

Clinical features



PEP typically develops during the third trimester of pregnancy (

image 1
).  The inflammation in the overstretched skin causes:



  • an initial pruritic, erythematous, papular rash that is limited to the abdominal striae.
  • subsequent centrifugal spread to the chest and extremities that spares the umbilicus, face, hands, and feet.

Diagnosis



PEP is diagnosed clinically.  No laboratory tests or biopsies are required for diagnosis.  Biopsy can be performed in nonclassic cases, but the features are nonspecific and are mostly used to exclude other diagnoses.

Management



Most patients with PEP can be treated with high-potency topical corticosteroids, which provide symptom relief.  Patients with severe symptoms may require a short course of oral corticosteroids.  Antihistamines may also be used for pruritus relief.



Patients can be managed with routine obstetric care until delivery because PEP is not associated with adverse maternal or fetal outcomes.

Prognosis



Most cases of PEP resolve within a few weeks postpartum and rarely reoccur in subsequent pregnancies.

Pemphigoid gestationis



Pemphigoid gestationis is a rare, pregnancy-specific autoimmune condition that causes vesicles and bullae (

).

Pathogenesis and risk factors 



Pemphigoid gestationis is an autoimmune disorder that is most likely caused by autoimmunity developed in the placenta, resulting in the formation of antibodies.  The antibodies of pemphigoid gestationis are directed against basement membrane protein BP180 (similar to bullous pemphigoid).  The formation of the antigen-antibody complex in the basement membrane causes inflammation and separation of the epidermal from the dermal layer of the skin.

Clinical presentation 



Patients typically develop symptoms during the second or third trimester of pregnancy.  The classic symptoms include:



  • Severe pruritus followed by a truncal rash
  • Rash beginning as periumbilical, urticarial papules and plaques that develop into vesicles and bullae
  • Rash spreading over the entire body but sparing the mucous membranes

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of pemphigoid gestationis can be made clinically, but a skin biopsy is confirmatory.  The skin biopsy undergoes direct immunofluorescence, which shows C3 complement deposits at the basement membrane (pathognomonic in pregnancy).  In some patients, an ELISA can be performed to test for antibodies against BP180, which is also specific for pemphigoid gestationis.

Management



The goal of treatment for pemphigoid gestationis is symptom control: relieving pruritus and limiting bullae formation.  Patients typically respond to high-potency topical corticosteroids (eg, triamcinolone).  Antihistamines (eg, loratadine, cetirizine) can also be added for pruritus relief.



Disease that is unresponsive to topical corticosteroids may require systemic corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) or, rarely, immunosuppressants (eg, cyclosporine, azathioprine).

Prognosis



Patients often have a flare at delivery and resolution of the disease postpartum, but pemphigoid gestationis may recur in subsequent pregnancies.  There is usually no increased risk to the fetus, but there are some cases of preterm delivery, fetal growth restriction, and neonatal pemphigoid gestationis (likely due to transplacental antibody transfer).

Pustular psoriasis of pregnancy



Pustular psoriasis of pregnancy, previously called impetigo herpetiformis, is a rare form of pustular psoriasis that occurs only during pregnancy.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Psoriasis is an inflammatory skin disorder characterized by hyperkeratosis (overgrowth of the stratum corneum) and epidermal hyperplasia.  Pregnancy can trigger immune function via hormonal changes that can exacerbate underlying psoriasis or cause a primary manifestation in patients who were predisposed to the condition.

Clinical features



Pustular psoriasis of pregnancy can occur at any gestational age but is most common in the third trimester.  Patients typically present with:



  • Erythematous plaques surrounded by sterile pustules
  • Lesions beginning on the skin folds (eg, axilla, inframammary region) and spreading outward to the trunk and extremities
  • Associated constitutional features of inflammation (eg, fever, malaise, leukocytosis)
  • No associated pruritus

Diagnosis



A presumptive diagnosis of pustular psoriasis of pregnancy can be made clinically, but a skin biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.



Biopsy results of pustular psoriasis are the same as in nonpregnant patients: spongiform pustules, parakeratosis (nucleated keratinocytes in the stratum corneum), and epidermal hyperplasia.



In addition, because of the systemic nature of pustular psoriasis of pregnancy and need for possible biologic agents for treatment, patients require additional testing with a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and renal and liver function testing.

Management



Due to the systemic inflammation associated with pustular psoriasis of pregnancy, there is a risk for placental insufficiency and fetal growth restriction.  Patients require serial growth ultrasonographies, and, if fetal growth restriction is identified, routine antepartum testing (eg, biophysical profile) and possible early delivery.



Maternal treatment is with systemic high-dose corticosteroids.  Patients with severe cases may require cyclosporine or biologic agents (eg, TNF inhibitors).

Prognosis



Fetal complications include the risk of fetal growth restriction, preterm delivery, and intrauterine fetal demise.  Most women have resolution of symptoms after delivery, but some occasionally have a flare during the immediate postpartum period.
